news.title: WestProp Champions Real Estate Growth at Prestigious ZimReal Indaba
news.content:
By Business Reporter WestProp Holdings this week, for the second consecutive year, took centre stage as themainline sponsorof the annualZimReal Property Investment Conference, a premier gathering that attracted over 300 participants, including property developers, owners, pension fund managers, bankers, and other industry professionals.

ThemedCementing Growth and Growing Value,the conference provided a platform to deliberate on the challenges and opportunities shaping Zimbabwes real estate sector.

Opening the event,WestProp Holdings CEO Ken Sharpehighlighted stark realities confronting the sector. He noted that while real estate contributes about20% to global GDPand12% across Africa, Zimbabwes property market accounts for a mere2% of the countrys GDP. Even more concerning, he said, was that the states mortgage contribution stands atjust 0.04%, compared to125% in Switzerland.

Meaningful growth cannot be achieved without unlocking capital, Sharpe stressed. Mortgages and long-term financing are the arteries of a functional property market. Without them, we build, but we do not grow. The absence of these instruments constrains not only developers, but also the dreams of ordinary Zimbabweans who aspire to own a home, a shop, or a piece of land.

In his closing remarks,WestProp Chairman Dr Michael Louisurged the industry to engage government in frank dialogue on the structural challenges undermining growth. He citedbureaucracy, infrastructure bottlenecks, policy inconsistencyparticularly around currency and exchange ratesas persistent barriersthat continue to erode investor confidence.

If we are serious about growth, these matters cannot remain at the fringes of policythey must be core agenda items, Dr Louis said. We cannot talk of cementing growth when the foundations are shifting beneath our feet.

Calling for stronger collaboration, he added: Policymakers must walk with the real estate industrynot behind us, not in front of us, but beside us as true partners in progress. Stable currency policy, consistent land administration, and predictable legal frameworks must not be ambitionsthey must be the norm.

Dr Louis concluded by stressing that the sectors mission extends beyond constructing buildings. What we are doing is about laying strong foundationsfor families, for businesses, and for national pride. If we think long-term, act collaboratively, and lead with vision, we will not just participate in the futurewe will shape it.

news.title: Mutangadura Burial Set for Today
news.content:
By A Correspondent Prominent businessmanJoseph Mutangadura, who was shot dead during a suspected armed robbery at his Ruwa home on Sunday night, will be laid to rest today atGoromonzi Turnoff Cemetery.

He was 67. Mutangadura was rushed to hospital after the attack but was pronounced dead on arrival.

Police have since launched a manhunt forseven suspectsbelieved to be behind the killing and have vowed to bring them to justice.

On Thursday, Zimbabweans woke up to social media reports claiming that one of the suspects had been arrested after a shootout with police in the Gazebo area. The posts further alleged that the suspect had confessed that some of his accomplices were hiding in Epworth.

However, the Zimbabwe Republic Police (ZRP) dismissed the reports as false.

National police spokesperson,Commissioner Paul Nyathi, urged the public to desist from circulating unverified information which could interfere with investigations.

People should disregard what is being circulated on social media. The police will officially pronounce any developments regarding the Mutangadura incident. Those putting out false information risk derailing ongoing investigations, said Comm Nyathi.

Meanwhile, family spokesperson and son of the late businessman,Munyaradzi Mutangadura, said the body will be collected from the parlour today before a church service at the family home in Ruwa. The body will then proceed to Goromonzi Turnoff Cemetery for burial.

The Ruwa community has been left in shock following the brutal killing.

We are still in disbelief. To take a life in cold blood like that is heartless. It makes us wonder if anyone is really safe, said one resident.

news.title: No Arrests In Mutangadura Murder Robbery
news.content:
By A Correspondent- The Zimbabwe Republic Police (ZRP) have dismissed as false, social media reports suggesting that a suspect has been arrested in connection with the murder of businessman Mr Joseph Mutangadura at his house in Ruwa during a suspected armed robbery on Sunday night.

He was pronounced dead on arrival at a hospital where he was rushed to after the shooting.

He was 67.

Police have since launched a manhunt for the seven suspects and vowed to bring them to book.

Thursday, Zimbabweans woke up to messages, flooding social media platforms alleging that one of the suspects had been arrested.

The social media messages even went on to give details of the alleged arrest.

In one post on Facebook, a message suggested that the said suspect was arrested in the Gazebo area after gunfire exchange with the law enforcement agents, who eventually cornered and apprehended him.

The post went on to say after the suspect was arrested, he revealed that some of his colleagues were staying in Epworth.

However, police dismissed the posts as false.

In an interview with Zimpapers yesterday, national police spokesperson Commissioner Paul Nyathi said the public should desist from spreading false information.

People should disregard what is being circulated on social media. The police will officially pronounce any developments regards the Mutangadura incident. Those who are putting information on social media which is not verified should be careful, lest they interfere with investigations and in the process derail what the police is doing, Comm Nyathi said.

He said investigations were ongoing.

Mr Mutangadura will be laid to rest at Goromonzi Turnoff Cemetery today.

According to the late businessmans son Mr Munyaradzi Mutangadura, the body of the deceased will be collected from the parlour on Friday and a church service will be held at his house in Ruwa where it will spend the night before it is buried on Saturday.

Meanwhile, the community is still in shock following the untimely death of Mr Mutangadura.

We are still in shock following this tragedy. There are people who are heartless out there. Killing someone in cold blood like that has left us wondering if all of us are really safe.

news.title: Pastor Forces Self On Male Teenager
news.content:
A Zvishavane-based pastor appeared before the Kwekwe Magistrates Court facing charges of aggravated indecent assault on an 18-year-old male.

The alleged incident reportedly occurred at the victims home in Redcliff on 11 August 2025.

According to court papers, the victim woke up to find himself being caressed by the accused, who had visited the family. When the victim questioned the pastors actions, he allegedly said the victim was too handsome and that the lack of a beard made him feel as though he was in bed with a woman.

The accused is further alleged to have forcibly removed the victims shorts and threatened him with a gun if he screamed or reported the incident.

The pastor allegedly forced the victim to lie on his stomach and assaulted him three times. Following the third assault, the accused reportedly demanded the victim perform a sexual act on him, which the victim did out of fear.

The accused is said to have left the premises at 06:30 hours.

The victim reportedly informed his aunt of the incident on the same day, and the matter was subsequently reported to Redcliff Police Station, leading to the pastors arrest.

The accused was remanded in custody and is expected to appear again in court on 27 August 2025 for trial.

news.title: Frustration Overshadows Zanu PF Grand Conference
news.content:
By A CorrespondentPreparations for the 22nd ZANU PF National Peoples Conference, set for October in Mutare, are gathering pace, with party leadership, led by National Chairperson Cde Oppah Muchinguri-Kashiri, arriving in the city on Thursday to assess progress.

However, public sentiment remains cautious, with many residents expressing doubt over whether the party can bring meaningful change after more than four decades in power.

After 45 years of Independence, what has ZANU PF actually done for ordinary people? asked one resident, speaking on condition of anonymity. We keep hearing about conferences and grand plans, but our daily strugglesjobs, healthcare, servicesremain unchanged.

Another citizen added, These meetings always feel like political theater. We want results, not just speeches and ceremonies. I cant see how this conference will be any different.

Observers note that while the party continues to tout its achievements and long history, public skepticism underscores a widening disconnect between leadership and ordinary citizens. Many question whether these high-profile gatherings genuinely address national challenges or serve primarily as political pageantry.

As preparations continue in Mutare, the spotlight remains on whether ZANU PF can translate rhetoric into tangible improvements for the Zimbabwean people.

news.title: Africa Must Abandon US Dollar, Declares Jacob Zuma
news.content:
By A Correspondent

Former South African President Jacob Zuma has called on African nations to ditch the US dollar and rally behind the BRICS alliance as an alternative route to economic freedom and stability.

Speaking at the 2025 UPSA Annual Leadership Lecture in Accra on Tuesday, August 19, Zuma said Africa could no longer afford to remain tied to Western financial systems that have historically disadvantaged the continent.

Africa needs to wake up and stop depending on systems that were designed to keep us poor, Zuma declared.

BRICS is the future for Africa. It offers us an opportunity to rewrite the global economic rules in our favor.

The event, themedThe Geopolitics and Geo-Economics of De-dollarisation: BRICS Currency Strategy, Lessons for Africas Common Currency and Beyond, focused on the growing debate around abandoning the dollar in international trade and strengthening African economic integration.

Zuma, who was instrumental in expanding BRICS during his presidency, described the bloccomprising Brazil, Russia, India, China and South Africaas a powerful tool for challenging global financial dominance. We have modelled our economies to serve other nations, yet the benefits have not been ours, he said. The dollar is oppressing everyone, let us create our own.

He also criticized decades of exploitation and dependency, arguing that Africas vast resources have not translated into real development. I do not think there is a continent that has suffered more than Africa, Zuma said. Its time to stand on our own.

The former president paid tribute to Ghanas role in the liberation struggle, hailing Dr. Kwame Nkrumah as a visionary who wanted Africa to lead its own destiny.

Education Minister Haruna Iddrisu praised UPSA for sparking dialogue on economic sovereignty, noting that these conversations are critical as Africa searches for independence beyond politics and into economics.

UPSA Vice-Chancellor Prof. Kwaku Mensah Mawutor emphasized the importance of the lecture series in shaping thought leadership on issues that affect Africas future. This is not just an academic exercise, Prof. Mawutor said. Its about equipping our students and the wider society to champion Africas voice in the global arena.

Since its inception in 2017, the UPSA Annual Leadership Lecture has hosted prominent figures, including former President John Agyekum Kufuor, Dr. Mohammed Ibn Chambas, and Otumfuo Osei Tutu II.

news.title: UNICEF boss meet Prof. Jiri
news.content:
UNICEF Representative Meets Zimbabwes Agriculture Ministry to Strengthen WASH Collaboration.

Harare, ZimbabweThe UNICEF Representative in Zimbabwe, Ms. Etona Ekole, paid a courtesy call on the Permanent Secretary in the Ministry of Lands, Agriculture, Fisheries, Water and Rural Development,Prof. Dr. Obert Jiri, to strengthen collaboration in the Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) sector. The meeting underscored the critical role of water in advancing child health, education, nutrition, and protection, while also addressing the pressing challenges of climate change and water scarcity.

During the engagement, Prof. Jiri highlighted the Ministrys mandate to coordinate all WASH activities nationwide through the National Action Committee. He outlined the robust structures already in place, including Rural WASH, Urban WASH, and Water Resources Management sub-committees, and commended UNICEF for its continued support in emergencies such as cholera outbreaks, as well as in information management through national dashboards that track sanitation and water supply across the country.

Ms. Ekole reaffirmed UNICEFs commitment to working with government in building resilience against climate shocks such as El Nio-induced droughts. She emphasized the disproportionate impact of water scarcity on children, noting how the burden of fetching water often compromises their protection, health, and development.

She also shared insights from her recent field visits to Matabeleland South and Manicaland, where UNICEF projects are improving access to safe water and strengthening community resilience.

Both parties stressed the importance of expanding partnerships in the water sector. Unlike health and education, which benefit from well-established consortia of development partners, WASH remains underfunded and has limited private sector involvement. Ms. Ekole proposed mobilizing bilateral and multilateral partnersincluding new actors such as China and local private sector playersto boost resource mobilization and investment in the sector.

The courtesy call concluded with a shared vision to align efforts with Zimbabwes National Development Strategy (NDS1 and NDS2) and to prepare for a high-level policy dialogue in early 2026. This platform is expected to rally stronger international and private sector partnerships for WASH, positioning water as a central driver of human capital development and resilience building.

news.title: Two South Africans Arrested, Fined in Harare
news.content:
By A Correspondent  Two South African nationals and their Zimbabwean accomplice were yesterday fined for obstructing traffic at the scene of the fatal Chitungwiza accident in which 17 people lost their lives in July.

Cooper Daniel Colin (33), Pretorius Walter James Seymour (51), and Germishuizen Danica (23) appeared before Harare magistrate Vakai Chikwekwe, where they pleaded guilty to the offence.

The trio was each ordered to pay a fine ofUS$200or face four months imprisonment.

The court heard that Seymour and Danica are crash data forensic experts based in Johannesburg. They entered Zimbabwe on August 20 on business visas, intending to investigate the Hunyani River Bridge accident scene where the fatal crash occurred.

Together with Colin, the two proceeded to the site and began marking scrape marks using paint and a tape measure. Their actions, however, obstructed the smooth flow of traffic between Harares central business district and Chitungwiza, leading to a traffic jam.

Chief Inspector Mapepa, who happened to be driving along the same route, confronted the group. After failing to provide a satisfactory explanation for conducting the exercise without notifying local authorities, the three were arrested.

news.title: ZANU PF Not Worried About The Rumours Of Chamisa’s New Political Party- Dr Mavaza
news.content:
By Dr Masimba Mavaza |

Nelson Chamisas new party, born out of his fallout with the Citizens Coalition for Change (CCC), is not regarded as a significant threat by the ruling party ZANU PF. According to ZANU PF, merely changing the name of a party does not alter its substanceit remains the same entity.

However, some analysts have raised concerns about Chamisas leadership style, pointing to a lack of transparency and democratic practices. These concerns have already tainted his new party before it has even taken off.

Chamisa was once a charismatic force in Zimbabwes opposition politics. Yet his charisma proved no match for the relatively unknown but highly calculating Sengezo Tshabangu, who forced him out of the CCC. Having faced mounting criticism over his leadership style in CCC, Chamisa now promises to unveil a new outfitthough with the same colour.

His leadership approach first drew controversy when he took control from Dr. Thokozani Khupe and went on to form the CCC, sidelining established party members while relying on a bottom-up structure driven by newcomers.

Chamisas leadership has often been described as a demigod style, where he exercises exclusive control over decision-making. This has led to allegations of undemocratic practices, such as imposing candidates and failing to conduct transparent internal polls. Consequently, CCCs stature as a credible alternative diminished amid internal divisions and power struggles.

Despite calls for a more structured and constitutional framework, Chamisas strategy remains vagueand this is now evident in his new party. Ironically, his erratic leadership has offered him a lesson: to observe how ZANU PF has maintained consistent leadership and constitutional order, while avoiding unstable movements that neglect peoples needs and development.

Chamisas lack of leadership depth has perpetuated divisions and infighting, further eroding his credibility as a viable alternative to ZANU PF. Senior opposition figures have voiced similar concerns, warning that his new party may suffer the same fate.

Key Challenges Facing Chamisas New Party Leadership-driven collapse: The party risks an early demise due to Chamisas own leadership weaknesses. Imported divisions: The internal conflicts and power struggles from CCC have already spilled over into the new formation. Lack of transparency: Chamisas leadership style continues to be criticized as undemocratic and opaque. Eroded credibility: Internal recalls and conflict have stained the partys image before it has even begun. Cronyism and paganism: The new party is weighed down by accusations of favouritism and questionable practices.

Despite all these challenges, Chamisa still believes he remains a popular figure in opposition politics. Yet, the success of his new party will depend on whether it can resolve these issues and project a united front.

For now, Chamisa and his party risk being little more than loud-sounding nothing.

His greatest dilemma is deciding who will serve as his vice president, perhaps, Thabani Mpofu Advocate Mpofu, who has been linked to attempts at reshaping the judiciary, is said to enjoy the backing of judges and senior members of the Judicial Service Commission.

By the time ZANU PF emerges from what critics call its Zvigananda opium, Chamisa may already have positioned his hand-picked judges to serve his political agenda.
